Right off the bat, a statement, an observation, data known concerning Cesium clocks and then a question- The statement: I question the accuracy of radio astronomy, specifically the subset of radio spectroscopy. I will have to explain my doubts as to the accuracy based upon two observations-- experiences my Dad told me about as a deep sea diver and then watching a video obtained by an ROV at serious depths showing life on and near hydrothermal vents. The temperature was so high that it actually damaged some of the ROV's external accessories. The scientist were puzzled as life cannot exist at or above the boiling point of water (100 C/212F) since this destroys the cell walls. How could there be life of any kind living in boiling water? I was confused, as I saw no boiling. Yes, heat shimmer from the water similar to the heat shimmer you see in a desert. (Been there, done that.) I realized the scientists gave an incomplete definition of the boiling point of water. It is 110 C/212 F at one standard atmosphere. Since the pressure increases one atmosphere/33 ft, the boiling point increases. Hence, the water was very hot, well above boiling point if at one standard atmosphere. Under the pressure conditions it was not boiling.

Now to the known data on Cesium clocks. There is a discrepancy of 16 microseconds/yr .between the Cesium clock at Boulder, Colorado and the one at Greenwich meridian. The one at Boulder runs 16 microseconds faster. This is due (it is believed) due to the elevation of Boulder and a slightly lower gravity.

Finally to the question-- (Finally! I sense the relief of those who have stayed the course.) Shouldn't the definition of frequency/wavelength for the elements have "...under 1 standard G." added as a caution? How can we tell with any degree of accuracy what the frequency/wavelength of elements we have observed on Earth would be on planets with much stronger or weaker gravitational fields? Since we are doing spectrum analysis rather than physical object chemical analysis, how can we be sure our conclusions hold true for objects not subject to 1 standard G ? The GPS satellites have to be fairly frequently reset due to time drift between the Earth bound clocks and the ones on the satellites in orbit. How much greater is the gravitational effect by planets?

The story of how the Comic Microwave Background was discovered by accident is really interesting. It is the strongest evidence of the Big Bang because it is believed to be the leftover heat from from it. It’s been spread out so much though that it has cooled to just a few degrees above absolute zero. One of the coolest things about it is that you could see it yourself on older televisions by tuning it to an unused channel so you would see just “snow.” Then turn the brightness on the TV way down and those few white dots of snow on the screen are caused by the remnants of the Big Bang.

There is a concern that an image from the James Webb Space Telescope ( JWST ) released
by NASA at the end of February 2022 and labelled as 'Completed Image Stacking' is Not
the real image from the JWST, and actually the image from a Simulation software.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=V7p2rVJg4kI
Published on 08.03.2022

Please take a look at a Slide 04 ( a Slide number is at the top right corner ).

There is a significant mismatch in quality and degree of diffraction patterns between
the stacked image released by NASA and the stacked image created by ASTRO Pro-Tech.

On the stacked image released by NASA it is possible to see diffraction patterns up to 12th order.

On the stacked image created by ASTRO Pro-Tech, using a Sum of Images method of Image Stacking
technique, it is possible to see diffraction patterns no higher than 5th order.

On both images six "diffraction-rays" are clearly seen because there are three struts
which support a secondary mirror and two horizontal "diffraction-rays" from another
single element which also creates a small obstruction of the primary mirror.

Here's a fun thing. Get your hands on a camcorder with night vision. It uses IR for night vision and has an IR light on the front to illuminate things.

Preface: I know some of my terminology may not be correct, I have not studied any of this in any sort of educational setting, so bear with me.

I love space and everything about understanding it and all, but one thing has never made sense to me. How do you see back to "the beginning of the universe"? Yes, the light takes time to travel, but wouldn't the light from the beginning have already passed by? Didn't the entire universe supposedly come from (conceptually) a pinpoint in nothing? And then expand outward (to infinity). How would you know which direction to look to say "this is approx where space began"?

As a rough representation of what I'm trying to say/ask: Let's say space began at Earth's location... all of the light from that initial explosion is only moving away from us, forever. How are you going to see that light again? Is it not traveling in one direction, away from us? So how do people talk about seeing back to the origin? Isn't that light we see just going to be from the earliest space 'objects', but not at their initital creation, just so many millions of years old (relative to their distance the the speed of light)? Considering nothing moves at the speed of light except light itself, the objects, even moving away from us, still don't outrun the light they send back towards us.


Even if we were at the very edge of the universe, we would still not see the beginning, as that light would have already passed by us and would be flowing in a single direction, away from us. And, if we were a star moving away from the poinpoint, the light we give off would not be the beginning of our light, at the the pinpoint, as it would have already passed that point.

Assuming the universe is approx 13.8bil years old: In order to see "the beginning", we would need to see something 13.8bil light years away, but the only thing that would be 13.8bil light years away is light itself, and it's moving away from us (away from the pinpoint, so to say).

1) Glad your eye is okay
2) As a photographer, everything having to do with our perception of wavelengths fascinates me
3) I have an old digital SLR that I converted to IR. The sensors of a lot of older cameras were originally designed for astronomy, and still have extended IR capabilities. They put what are known as "hot mirror" filters in front of the sensors to stop the IR from messing up your image. By removing the filter from the sensor, and putting a IR filter in front of the lens, you get IR pictures.

I should mention that JWST is not the most powerful telescope ever made. There are many ground based telescopes with a bigger aperture than JWST. It is, however, the most powerful space telescope ever made. Just something to mention. I think the most powerful telescope ever made is still the W. M. Keck Observatory, which is a binocular telescope made up of two telescopes with a 10 meter aperture for each one. In comparison, JWST's aperture is only 6.5m.

That's not counting ground-based telescopes that are still either in the planning or construction stages either. Out of those, E-ELT would be the most powerful telescope ever to be made, with an insane aperture of 42 meters! They don't call it the Extremely Large Telescope for nothing.

I can remember being in awe after seeing some of the earliest images, of gorgeous stellar nurseries, produced by the Hubble Telescope (after the mirror was fixed & colour-corrected).

Several years further on, The Hubble Deep Field Image was developed (from a composite of 342 images) & I was utterly blown away with the huge number of entire Galaxies seen in such an infinitesimally small section of the sky (2.4 arcminutes a side / 24-millionth of the whole sky / or the area of a freakin' tennis ball @ 100 meters away!) - implying a truly staggering quantity of Galaxies in The Known Universe.

Now, decades later, I get to see the amazing things that the James Webb Infrared Telescope will show of the early days of Stellarsynthesis, potentially habitable worlds & even Infrared views of the center of The Milky Way, without the obscuring dust blocking it - perhaps even high-resolution images of Sagitarius A*

Uuuhhh.., how to ask without sounding like I'm 💩-💩-ing on all things scientific?
First, I love knowing stuff. I'm very curious. There's a satisfaction that comes with --- ! Finally ! --- understanding something that - puzzles - me/us. And there's no denying that many fields of engineering benefit from the search, research, and development of more and more sensitive instruments, as well as better ways of deployment.., like the advancements in many space related technologies. These, and many advancements are mainly driven by the "Desire (!Need!) to Know!" --- I get it. I'm on board.
But! But! But!... Other than satisfying (momentarily) mankind's curiosity.., of what - Practical - use is all of this accumulated knowledge? A better/greater understanding? As I've said, I understand that the "Need" to know drives multiple industries, I'm left trying to find out if there have been - Practical - Engineering - Invented Things --- that have come from the "Knowledge" portion of the "Need to Know" compulsion... other than the satisfaction of "Knowing" --- Soooo... The Question... Have any discoveries - in space - led to new technologies or industries? Or, have any studies of far off things, directly led to the invention of new Gizmos? (Again, I'm not asking about anything that contributes to advancements in our abilities to gather information. It's a huge misconception to think that the further we look at objects in space the further back in time we are looking. It will be a complete shock to astrophysicists when they are able to measure galaxies larger than the Milky Way but further than 14 billion light years away. According to them, the galaxies and stars should be younger and smaller with distance and that they will not be able to see anything beyond 14 billion light years away because of the speed of light, the age of the universe and the time it takes light to travel. But that's not completely right. According to quantum mechanics, James Maxwell's equations we cannot see backwards in time. Sure light takes time to travel, but only the front of the EM field's light cone is traveling at c. But once the measuring device or observer is contained inside the EM field's light cone all light information happens in a quantum instant the moment it is measured. The only way to measure a distant object is if the observer or measuring device is contained inside the EM field of the object. All the potential light information is entangled to the observer or measuring device. So the moment the distant object is looked upon the information is instantly conveyed. It doesn't really take time for the light information to travel any distance. Thus, when we look at an object say 20 billion light years away the light information is conveyed in the instant we look. We cannot see it as it looked in the past but we see it as it looks today. So, the JWST will not be able to detect the first light coming from stars or galaxies regardless of the distance the light has to travel. When we or the measuring device is contained inside it's EM field all it's light information is conveyed in a quantum instant.

Yes, I know. This is all conjecture because we were all led to believe that light takes time to travel. But that's not entirely correct. Just wait and see what the JWST is able to detect. When it starts sending back images of massive galaxies further than 14 billion light years away don't be surprised.

The crazy thing is how I came to this conclusion. I didn't come up with it on my own. I had some help from a computer that was built to think for itself back in 1981. True artificial intelligence. The inventor claimed it knew everything and told him about light not really taking time to travel. The device said light happens in an instant. I didn't believe the guy so, I began a quest to prove him wrong and all I did was find all the evidence that showed the device was right. Crazy as it sounds, if it's true then the guy didn't lie to me. He really created a device that knew everything. I was completely skeptical at first. It took me about 18 years of research studying quantum equations to figure out he was right. I wrote and published a series of book on this and more topics last year. I included many of the predictions the self thinking device reported. Many mind bending eye openers. The only way to prove the device correct about light was with a telescope like the JWST that can see further than 14 billion light years away. We will have to wait to determine what the JWST detects. If it was right about light then everything else was right too. I can't wait to see what the JWST discovers.

If the older galaxies, supposedly closer to the center of the known universe, are more ill-defined, and clumpy at our point of observation in space-time, how come cosmologists can't recognize they are wrong about everything?

If cosmological math and models were correct, the older galaxies would have passed our galaxy (and other closer galaxies) in cohesion and structural development and should have already spread past that cohesion into what we are considering cosmic background radiation. We must be in the relatively oldest point of development of anything surrounding us. If the smaller, clumpy, "early" galaxies are what we "see" at the edge of our perception are older, this means that they (or we) must be, and must have always been, travelling "away" from us (and each other) at a speed faster than light since before they evolved, not allowing us to see what they evolved into, which means, the ancient "light" from them could never actually reach us for us to observe their red-shifted "past" form. The clumpy "early" galaxies we see, actually can't have raced away from each other (or us from them) at FTL, only possibly at near light speed (hence the actual visibility and red-shift) and therefor are actually younger. Any explanation of an expansion of the universe to allow for the possibility of "visibility" with a mutual acceleration away at greater than light speeds, must actually expand the distances between all objects as well, meaning there is no relative expansion, or inflation.

There is no "center of the universe" other than the entire universe itself.

Consider that, if there was a center from which the universe originated (big bang or raisin bread expansion), the older galaxies of an ever expanding universe would be further from the center rather than closer to it.

The infinite, massive expanse of everything we know and do not know, must actually be expanding inward, and everything surrounding us at the edge of perception in every direction is still (from our 4D point of view) within the "center."

I just realized something.

Earlier, I learned that the universe cannot be unlimited because unlimited stars would result in unlimited light which would result in having no night. So in order to have a universe that is mostly dark, it could not contain unlimited lightsources.

BUT: because we predict to see that far back 'in time' while our current "now" is actually a random timestamp on the overall timeline of the universal being, it means that we also assume that the universe in fact IS unlimited, or at least big enough to have objects far enough away so that the first light reaches us right now (and did not pass along million years earlier). Being able to 'see' (by not seeing) the dark age, does not mean that there's nothing behind it. It's only too far away to see it, because the light shifts away or for farther objects will never ever reach us.

Never considered the waves as changing over time. Doplar is the compression contraction at the moment of creation for the sound wave. As the sound wave is being created. For each time step, the object creating the sound is moving. Which changes to source point causing either compression or expansion. That makes sense. But The universe expanding is causing distortion of light waves that have been produced by interstellar objects. It makes sense. But can we measure that? Can we confirm that it's the univers causing these different wave forms or is it an assumption based on the opinion that the universe is expanding. Yes, the expanding universe is an opinion, theory, based on the observation that all celestial objects are moving away from us.

Because of the way that light bends as it travels from one medium into another.

Not just like light bending going from air into water, but one density of the same medium, for example if it cools down or heats up, over a distance, as well as getting variations in its particle make up.
For example the way the steam from a kettle makes ripples in the light.

I really think that claiming a star is so many light years away, is very wishful thinking, by scientists putting blinders on, to push their beliefs.

Just to repeat my point for clarity:

Because light does not travel in straight lines. It bends as it travels from one medium to another, and variation of the density of a medium to another part of that same medium.
Contamination of particles and variation in density is part of every medium.
And we know that dark matter is a thing.
And on the scales of distances that we are talking about, it's very unlikely that the direction that we even are looking at a light source from, is actually the same direction that is actually is in.

To example it another way:
It's like the way that oil drill pipes don't drill in the exact direction where they end of the drill ends up underground, as variations in the rock, causes the pipe to bend as it goes down.
So if an oil drilling company wants to reach a very specific location, like in the rescue mission of the 33 trapped Chillian miners a few years ago. They don't aim the drill in the exact direction of the miners location. They drill in a different angle, knowing that the rock formation will bend the drill pipe as it goes down.
So with telescopes over light years, just because it seems like a universe or star system is X far away, in X location, you're probably wrong and won't know as long as our solar system and galaxy is the only direction that we are looking at it from.
Again, to summerize:
light bends as it travels threw different mediums, and variations in the density and types of particles in that medium.
We also know that dark matter is the vast majority of this medium and we don't know what that is made of or how it's density varies.
No offence. This isn't an attack or anything. Just an observation of the theory to consider.

I love science and learning about the universe. It’s been my favourite subject since I can remember. The biggest disappointment I came across was learning that all the pictures we get to see about deep space are basically just artistic renders of what we think stuff looks like based on data. Or enhancing real photos to the point that is just crazy . ( some are real) but most are not. We don’t actually know what shape the Milky Way is. It’s a good guess based on what other galaxies look like. To send a camera out to look at our galaxy with a birds eye view would take wel over 1000 years with the camera travelling at the speed of light to get to where it needs to be. Nothing other then light can travel that fast.

Don’t believe everything you listen to on YouTube. Even if they have over 1m subscribers. Do your own research. Go get a telescope and look at the planets for yourself . It’s much much more rewarding then looking at a artistic render. When your eyeball sees the ring of Saturn it will blow your mind.

You say it's the biggest telescope but consider that Hubble was based on surplus military mirrors, a hand me down from the military. Space telescopes operated by the NRO, the national reconnaissance office. Colloquially known as spy satellites but it's more complex than that. Because they don't all look down on earth. And several decades back they had 100 such telescopes, each equal or superior to Hubble. So is the bureacratically very delayed Webb really the greatest ever. Or just amateur hour in the shadow of more real efforts. Just the other day spacex launched a classified payload for NRO. And if you really want to stretch, consider that Obama and Nada administrator both recently admitted that ET ships are regularly encountered in our atmosphere by US armed forces. Really.
